body:
@fredbi  It's a pretty generous interpretation of 'enhancement' to not consider this a bug ;)

Would you all be open to a patch that inverts _all_ applicable generated tags, i.e. use double quotes and escape double quotes within the tags, like so:

     "json:\"ScheduledReleases\" xml:\"KeyValuePair`2\""

This would fix all occurrences of similar behavior and the only objection I can think of is aesthetic. But as it's generated code which shouldn't be touched anyway, it would be an acceptable solution from my point of view. I would be willing to contribute a patch.
@a2800276  if you consider a patch, could you please separate the case when escaping is necessary (like adding a guard to detect the presence of a backtick)?

> I don't think it's possible to do that with the current template system

@a2800276  consider making it a function in either `struct.go` or in the `repo_template.go` funcmap.

> On a related note, I'm reluctant to start work on a fix because I can't get the unit tests in generator to pass. Is this a bug I should report or is there something I need to do beyond just calling go test?

./gen-debug.sh # <- this regenerate your bindata.go in debug mode (live template assets)
go test -v -failfast

@fedbi thanks for the pointers, I'll start poking around.

I'm afraid the generator tests are still failing, though:

```
$ cd generator
$ ./gen-debug.sh && go test -v -failfast > still_failing
```

[still_failing.txt](https://github.com/go-swagger/go-swagger/files/5559831/still_failing.txt)

Does the above run on your machine successfully? I'm using the "kevinburke" fork of go-bindata as suggested in the docs, maybe this advice is out of date?

The problem with the tests lies in `assertImports`, it's expecting:

```
"swagger_nogo030569067/packages_mangling/client/abc_linux"
```

as an import, but a fully qualified (if mangled) path is being generated:

```
"github.com/go-swagger/go-swagger/generator/swagger_nogo030569067/packages_mangling/client/abc_linux"
```

My problem is that the only other usage of `assertImports` (in generat_test.go) checks for  fully qualified paths, and that test passes. Both tests were introduced in the same commit. Unfortunately, I'm not able to judge what the correct & expected behavior is, but it seems that (at least) one of the cases is probably genuinely broken or wrong... Let me know whether I should open this as a separate issue ...

Yes, it works fine locally and on CI as well: all the tests pass.
It is okay to have a fully qualified package import. The regexp should match either way.
You may open this as a separate issue. It is likely that this is dealing with your build environment.

> It is okay to have a fully qualified package import. The regexp should match either way.

The regexp matches the surrounding quotes ... So it needs to literally match the import statement. I'll have a look at CI and will raise a seperate issue if it doesn't become apparent why it's different here. Thanks!

issue.title: Generate example struct tag if example is provided
issue.body:
Fixes #2445 

My use case might be a bit weird. I have a service, let's call it A which calls service B. Service B has a swagger spec which I use to generate a client for it. Service A has a few cases where it will straight up return a model generated by go-swagger from the spec of service B.

When I generate the swagger spec for service A, I have a problem because the example field in the swagger spec of service B is not rendered on the models. So the service A swagger spec does not contain the examples, which is not ideal.

It might sound a bit convoluted but that's how we setup our thing. We use https://github.com/swaggo/swag to generate the service spec (legacy reasons), and it needs that example tag.

issue.title: refactored, documented and tested tags in models
issue.body:
* fixes #2423 - acknowledged fixed
* refactored tag rendering: use strings.Builder, cleaned up redundancies with xml tags,
  used stdlib strconv.CanBackQuote instead of Contains
* now always renders extra tags in order specified by the user (e.g. --struct-tags example,db)
* now renders xml tags if requested in the CLI opts, even when no consumes/produces is set with xml
* added unit tests for model tag generation
* added doc on how to play with struct tags

Signed-off-by: Frederic BIDON <fredbi@yahoo.com>
